Everyday Science.question: Why does a sealed bag of chips puff up on an airplane?
Everyday Science.reason: The air inside the bag is at ground pressure; the cabin pressure is lower, so the bag pushes out.

Everyday Science.question: Why does blowing on hot soup cool it down?
Everyday Science.reason: Moving air carries away the water vapor, speeding up evaporation which absorbs heat.

Everyday Science.question: Why is the ocean salty but rivers are fresh?
Everyday Science.reason: Rivers carry trace minerals (salt) to the sea. Water evaporates, but salt stays and accumulates.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a door handle shock you in winter?
Everyday Science.reason: Dry winter air prevents charge from leaking off your body, building up static.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a heavy boat float?
Everyday Science.reason: It pushes away a weight of water equal to its own weight (Buoyancy).

Everyday Science.question: Why does coffee spill when you stop walking suddenly?
Everyday Science.reason: The coffee 'wants' to keep moving forward when the cup stops (Newton's 1st Law).

Everyday Science.question: Why does the sun appear red at sunset?
Everyday Science.reason: Sunlight passes through more atmosphere, scattering away blue light and leaving red.

Everyday Science.question: Why do soda bubbles rise?
Everyday Science.reason: Gas (CO2) is much less dense than the liquid soda.

Everyday Science.question: Why does wet laundry dry faster on a windy day?
Everyday Science.reason: Wind removes the humid air directly around the clothes, allowing more evaporation.

Everyday Science.question: Why don't birds get shocked on power lines?
Everyday Science.reason: Electricity needs a path to the ground. Touching only one wire completes no circuit.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a shower curtain blow inward when the water runs?
Everyday Science.reason: Fast moving water/air creates lower pressure inside the shower (Bernoulli principle).

Everyday Science.question: Why does metal feel colder than wood at the same room temperature?
Everyday Science.reason: Metal steals heat from your hand faster than wood, triggering 'cold' sensation.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a full freezer consume less energy than an empty one?
options: Solids hold cold better than air
Everyday Science.reason: Cold air spills out when you open the door. Frozen food stays put and retains the cold.

Everyday Science.question: Why does salt melt ice on roads?
Everyday Science.reason: Saltwater freezes at a much lower temperature than pure water.

Everyday Science.question: Why do astronauts float in the ISS?
Everyday Science.reason: They are falling around the Earth at the same speed as the station (Orbit).

Everyday Science.question: Why does sound travel faster in water than air?
Everyday Science.reason: Molecules are packed tighter in liquid, transmitting vibration energy faster.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a bike stay upright when moving?
Everyday Science.reason: A combination of wheel spin stability and the rider steering into leans.

Everyday Science.question: Why does the moon have phases?
Everyday Science.reason: As the moon orbits, we see varying angles of the side lit by the Sun.

Everyday Science.question: Why does popcorn pop?
Everyday Science.reason: Tiny drop of water inside the kernel turns to steam, pressurizing until it explodes.

Everyday Science.question: Why is the top of a mountain colder?
Everyday Science.reason: Air expands and cools as pressure drops at higher altitudes (Adiabatic cooling).

Everyday Science.question: If you hold a balloon in a car and brake, which way does the balloon move?
Everyday Science.reason: The heavier air inside the car rushes forward (inertia), pushing the lighter balloon backward.

Everyday Science.question: Why does hot water sound different than cold water when poured?
Everyday Science.reason: Hot water is less viscous (thinner), changing the pitch of the splash.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a whip crack?
Everyday Science.reason: The wave traveling down the whip accelerates the tip to supersonic speeds.

Everyday Science.question: Why does rubbing alcohol feel cold on skin?
Everyday Science.reason: Alcohol evaporates very quickly, absorbing significant heat energy from your skin.

Everyday Science.question: Why is the sky blue?
Everyday Science.reason: Rayleigh scattering affects short wavelengths (blue) more than long ones (red).

Everyday Science.question: Why do golf balls have dimples?
Everyday Science.reason: Dimples create a turbulent boundary layer that reduces aerodynamic drag.

Everyday Science.question: Why does honey crystallize?
Everyday Science.reason: Honey is a supersaturated sugar solution; glucose naturally tends to separate out.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a swinging pendulum eventually stop?
Everyday Science.reason: Energy is slowly lost to air drag and friction at the pivot point.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a candle flame point up?
Everyday Science.reason: Convection currents push the hot gases upward against gravity.

Everyday Science.question: Why does fresh egg sink and old egg float?
Everyday Science.reason: As an egg ages, moisture leaves and air enters, increasing the air cell size.

Everyday Science.question: Why does shaking a soda can make it explode?
Everyday Science.reason: Shaking mixes gas into liquid and attaches bubbles to the sides, which expand rapidly when opened.

Everyday Science.question: Why does stretching a rubber band make it warm?
Everyday Science.reason: Aligning the polymer chains reduces entropy (order), releasing heat energy (Thermodynamics).

Everyday Science.question: Why does light form a rainbow?
Everyday Science.reason: Raindrops act like prisms, bending (refracting) and reflecting sunlight into colors.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a spinning top stay upright?
Everyday Science.reason: Conservation of angular momentum resists changes to the axis of rotation.

Everyday Science.question: Why do two sheets of paper stick together if you blow between them?
Everyday Science.reason: Fast air has lower pressure; higher pressure outside pushes the papers together.

Everyday Science.question: Why does dry ice smoke?
Everyday Science.reason: The extreme cold causes water vapor in the air to condense into visible fog.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a magnet fall slowly through a copper pipe?
Everyday Science.reason: Moving magnetic field creates electric currents in copper that oppose the motion (Lenz's Law).

Everyday Science.question: Why does stainless steel not rust?
Everyday Science.reason: Chromium reacts with oxygen to form a invisible protective skin that prevents rust.

Everyday Science.question: Why does fluorescent light hum?
Everyday Science.reason: Magnetic constriction in the ballast causes plates to vibrate at 60Hz (mains frequency).

Everyday Science.question: Why does vegetable oil stop pasta water from foaming?
Everyday Science.reason: Oil disrupts the starch structure and surface tension that allows bubbles to stack.

Everyday Science.question: Why do mirrors flip left-right but not up-down?
Everyday Science.reason: Mirrors reflect along the Z-axis (depth); your brain interprets this as a rotation.

Everyday Science.question: Why does boiling water sometimes freeze faster than cold water (Mpemba effect)?
Everyday Science.reason: Complex factors like evaporation reducing mass and convection currents allow rapid cooling.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a bike chain get loose over time?
Everyday Science.reason: The metal plates don't stretch; the pivot pins wear down, creating gaps (effective lengthening).

Everyday Science.question: Why does sunlight bleach colors but darken skin?
Everyday Science.reason: UV breaks down dye molecules (fading) but triggers protective pigment production in cells (tanning).

Everyday Science.question: Why does a tea bag spin if you empty it and light it (Rocket Tea Bag)?
Everyday Science.reason: The flame heats air inside the cylinder, creating an updraft that lifts the lightweight ash.

Everyday Science.question: Why does scratching an itch feel good?
Everyday Science.reason: Mild pain from scratching distracts the spinal cord from transmitting the itch signal.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a satellite not fall to Earth?
Everyday Science.reason: It has enough sideways speed that the Earth curves away as fast as the satellite falls.

Everyday Science.question: Why does blacktop road shimmer on a hot day?
Everyday Science.reason: Hot air near the ground bends light rays upward, creating an image of the sky on the ground.

Everyday Science.question: Why does microwave food cool down so fast?
Everyday Science.reason: Microwaves heat water; once steam escapes (evaporation), the heat energy is lost quickly.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a tuning fork sound louder against a table?
Everyday Science.reason: The fork forces the large surface area of the table to vibrate, moving more air.

Everyday Science.question: Why does water stay in a bucket swung overhead?
Everyday Science.reason: Inertia wants the water to travel straight; the bucket forces it curve, pinning it to the bottom.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a camera lens look dark even if glass is clear?
Everyday Science.reason: Lenses trap light to focus it on the sensor; very little light reflects back to your eye.

Everyday Science.question: Why does static shock hurt more in dry weather?
Everyday Science.reason: Moist air bleeds charge away naturally; dry air allows massive voltage potentials to accumulate.

Everyday Science.question: Why does blowing between two cans make them roll together?
Everyday Science.reason: Fast air decreases pressure between them; higher atmospheric pressure outside pushes them in.

Everyday Science.question: Why does aluminum foil spark in the microwave?
Everyday Science.reason: Thin metal can't conduct the high currents induced by microwaves, causing electrons to jump air gaps.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a heavy coat make you warm? (It generates no heat)
Everyday Science.reason: It traps a layer of air (a poor conductor) near your body, preventing your own heat from escaping.

Everyday Science.question: Why does gasoline smell usually mean a leak?
Everyday Science.reason: Gasoline is highly volatile; fumes travel far and fast even from small sources.

Everyday Science.question: Why does coffee cream mix itself eventually (Diffusion)?
Everyday Science.reason: Random collisions of molecules spread the cream evenly over time without stirring.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a piece of paper fall slower than a crumpled ball?
Everyday Science.reason: Flat paper has high surface area for air to push against; crumpling reduces area relative to weight.

Everyday Science.question: Why does looking through a pinhole improve vision without glasses?
Everyday Science.reason: It restricts light to the center of the lens, reducing blur caused by refractive errors.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a raw egg spin differently than a hard-boiled egg?
Everyday Science.reason: The liquid inside a raw egg resists spinning (inertia), acting as a brake; solid eggs spin as one unit.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a candle go out if you blow on it too hard?
Everyday Science.reason: The fast air pushes the flame away from the wax vapor (fuel) and cools the reaction zone.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a wet finger feel cooler in the wind?
Everyday Science.reason: Evaporation requires energy (latent heat), which is taken from your skin.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a magnet lose strength when heated?
Everyday Science.reason: Heat energy causes atoms to vibrate, jiggling the aligned magnetic domains out of order.

Everyday Science.question: Why does distant pavement look wet (Mirage)?
Everyday Science.reason: Hot air near the road bends light from the sky upward; you see the sky on the ground.

Everyday Science.question: Why does sucking on a helium balloon make your voice high?
Everyday Science.reason: Sound travels faster in light helium, changing the resonance frequencies of your vocal tract.

Everyday Science.question: Why does sugar glow when crushed (Triboluminescence)?
Everyday Science.reason: Breaking asymmetric crystal bonds separates charges; nitrogen in air glows when charges jump.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a siphon work?
Everyday Science.reason: Gravity pulls the liquid in the longer leg down, creating low pressure that pulls liquid up the short leg.

Everyday Science.question: Why does an airplane wing lift?
Everyday Science.reason: It's a mix of Newton (deflecting air down) and Bernoulli (low pressure on top).

Everyday Science.question: Why does adding salt to ice make it colder?
Everyday Science.reason: Salt forces ice to melt; melting requires heat, which is drawn from the mixture itself.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a bike wheel resist turning when spinning fast?
Everyday Science.reason: Angular momentum makes the spinning wheel resist changing its orientation.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a shower curtain stick to you?
Everyday Science.reason: A horizontal vortex driven by the spray lowers pressure inside the curtain.

Everyday Science.question: Why does blue light focus differently than red (Chromatic aberration)?
Everyday Science.reason: Glass bends (refracts) different wavelengths by different amounts; blue bends more.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a grape produce plasma in a microwave?
Everyday Science.reason: The grape's size/water acts as a dielectric resonator, concentrating energy to ionize air.

Everyday Science.question: Why does hot water freeze faster (Mpemba)? Specific mechanism.
Everyday Science.reason: It's a complex combination of evaporation, dissolved gases, and convection currents.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a heavy chain falling from a beaker leap upwards (Mold effect)?
Everyday Science.reason: The chain links lever against the pile/beaker rim, pushing the chain up as they are pulled down.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a magnet fall slowly in copper (Lenz Law)? Energy source?
Everyday Science.reason: Falling kinetic energy is converted into electrical currents (heat) in the copper.

Everyday Science.question: Why does fluid speed up in a narrow pipe (Venturi)?
Everyday Science.reason: Mass must be conserved; same amount of fluid must pass through smaller area, so speed increases.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a inverted spoon in stream pull into water?
Everyday Science.reason: Fluid tends to follow curved surfaces; the reaction force pulls the spoon into the flow.

Everyday Science.question: Why does a Prince Rupert's Drop explode if tail is cut?
Everyday Science.reason: The outside is in extreme compression, inside in tension; breaking the tail releases the tension instantly.
